description: From Middle English trevet, from Old English trefet, borrowed from Latin tripēs, tripedis (“tripod”).

entries.meaning: A stand with three short legs, especially for cooking over a fire.
examples: They collected wood and built back the fire and they fetched rocks to make a trivet and there they set the bucket to boil.

entries.meaning: A stand, sometimes with short, stumpy feet, used to support hot dishes and protect a table; a coaster.
A weaver's knife used to cut out the wire that was used to form a pile.<ref>1874, Edward H. Knight, American Mechanical Dictionary
